utterance: One, two. I believe I am going to win. There!
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: beaten by two points now how do you feel?
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: I think my wife is the cleverest little woman in the world ! Shall we try another game ?
speaker: Clarence Beckington

utterance: In just a moment. Clar- ence aren't you glad you married a girl who can beat you at billiards?
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: Indeed I am, dear. When I was a bachelor, on snowy nights like this, when none of the men came around and I was too lazy to go up to the club, the butler would come and play with me. Old Thomas taught me when I was a boy ; he is a very good player, but it rather lowered my self- esteem to have my own butler give me every other game just as though I was still fourteen years old.
speaker: Clarence Beckington

utterance: So you think I am an improve- ment on Thomas, do you?
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: Oh, yes, a lot. You don't know how awfully amusing you look when you play your eyes get so bright and your hair tips so becomingly side- ways.
speaker: Clarence Beckington

utterance: Clarence, you are a mean tease.
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: Stop, Bertha ; you'll bend the cue.
speaker: Clarence Beckington

utterance: Now, Bertha, don't you dare beat me again. If you do I shall get out the marriage service and read you your proper duty toward your husband.
speaker: Clarence Beckington

utterance: My proper duty towards my hus- band, is to beat him if I can.
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: Just so, my dear; see if you can again.
speaker: Clarence Beckington

utterance: Hello, Gordon White, make your- self at home. Don't speak to Bertha or you will upset her ; she has been getting an aim for the last half hour.
speaker: Clarence Beckington

utterance: You don't mind if we go on, do you? You know you may smoke.
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: Good evening, Jim. how is the game how many are you ?
speaker: Jim Ashley

utterance: I won the last game and I'm crazy to beat this. I'm a point ahead.
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: Tell me, my dear young lady, what have you been doing this long winter day ?
speaker: Gordon White

utterance: Oh, I've been doing such a lot of things. Which reminds me, I have been so hoping all day that you would come in this evening, for there is some- thing I want you to do specially for me ; will you?
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: Anything.
speaker: Gordon White

utterance: I want you to buy me a doll,
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: I don't mind your scoffing one bit. If Mrs. Beckington wants a doll I will certainly get her one. My dear young lady, won't your hus- band let you have a doll ?
speaker: Gordon White

utterance: Clarence, do you think Mr. White would like to hear about the girl bachelor?
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: What is a girl bachelor?
speaker: Gordon White

utterance: What is it? I too am anxious to be enlightened. What's a girl bache- lor? Is White a girl bachelor?
speaker: Jim Ashley

utterance: I should think it was one of those dudes in trained frock coats one sees on Fifth Avenue about five o'clock in the afternoon.
speaker: Gordon White

utterance: Do let me speak.
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: And may I ask, is this interesting girl bachelor a gay young thing between forty and fifty, whose portraits it is as much a charity to buy as the dolls for your Christmas tree ? Does she do such nice illustrations only they won't sell?
speaker: Gordon White

utterance: We don't doubt that her studio is superb, but was she very emancipated ? White wants to know.
speaker: Jim Ashley

utterance: I don't.
speaker: Gordon White

utterance: Yes, lie does ; he wants to know if she has short hair and if she wears trousers. He says he has heard of a woman artist who did.
speaker: Jim Ashley

utterance: Mrs. Beckington, I implore you to introduce me to her. Do you think she could make dress shirts? Heav- ens! what a saving. White, you can't have her ; I spoke first.
speaker: Jim Ashley

utterance: Don't worry, my boy; I'll never marry any woman unless she can make high hats and patent-leather shoes.
speaker: Gordon White

utterance: I should have thought you would have been more sympathetic. She is the most charming girl I ever saw, and you seem to think that a woman who has any brains must be an ugly little old maid ! Miss Craig isn't an old maid and she never will be. As we were coming away I said to Dorothy that it seemed funny such a nice girl hadn't married, and she quite snapped at me. She said, ' Oh, Miss Craig is a girl bache- lor;' that's where I got the name. It just suits her and I think it so pretty.
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: I'll not tell you another thing about her. You sha'n't any of you know her, and Dorothy Mason and I will keep her all to ourselves. Oh, just one thing more recollecting herself: my brother Philip knows her; I met him going in just as we were coming away.
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: The saying about the devil is trite, but since I hear my name you might as well tell me what it is all about. Good evening how comfortable you all look Bertha, as usual, posing as an angel in a cloud of tobacco-smoke.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: How did you come to know her?
speaker: UNKNOWN

utterance: Who, Bertha? Met her when she was a baby.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: No, not Bertha; the girl bache- lor.
speaker: UNKNOWN

utterance: What are you all talking about? What an extraordinary reception ! If I did not know the ways of this erra- tic household I should think you were all slightly insane. Who is a girl bachelor, and what do you mean?
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: Oh, it's all my fault. Mrs. Mason took me to Miss Craig's studio this afternoon, and I .have been telling them about her. A girl like her, who earns her own living, is called a girl bachelor, you see.
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: My dear sister, don't you think it is rather hard that because a young woman is so un- fortunate as to have to earn her own living that she must be called by a slang name?
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: Were you going to Mrs. How- ard's ? I stopped in there on my way up and she asked me if you wouldn't be around.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: Who is going with me? Clarence has such a cold I can't possibly martyrize him.
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: Bring her back safely, Jim.
speaker: Clarence Beckington

utterance: I must be getting along, there's a meeting up at the club that I ought to get to before to-mor- row. Good night, Philip ; good night, Beckington.
speaker: Gordon White

utterance: Nice fellow, old White. How he wears. When I was about twelve years old I can remember his looking just as he does now.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: I wonder if it is still snowing. If it is, the horses will be buried, Bertha is staying so late.
speaker: Clarence Beckington

utterance: It makes me think of college.
speaker: Clarence Beckington

utterance: Yes, the snow always makes me think of college too, and our nights on the bob runners down those long icy hills. Talk about toboggan slides and skeeing and every other kind of sport, they don't come any- where near our old sleds.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: Is there anything the matter, old man ? You haven't been your- self for the last few days I suppose it's the old story.
speaker: Clarence Beckington

utterance: Do you remember my first boyish raptures over Margaret ? I wanted to tell you the first of all. I am sure you will congratu- late me, her husband is dead; we are going to be married.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: I'm awfully glad, Philip.
speaker: Clarence Beckington

utterance: Well, I must be going along ; good night.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: There was something I wasn't going to say, but I will. I wish, Clarence, that you would ask Bertha to be kind to that little Miss Craig, the artist. I have been going there a good deal lately and she is very much alone in the world. There is some trouble hanging over her just now and a woman friend might help her.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: It will be a reparation if Bertha will be kind to her
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: Why, you old bear, you don't seem a bit glad that I've come home. Were you doing a little thinking while I was out of the house so I couldn't disturb you ? How very solemn you look.
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: Philip is going to be married, my dear
speaker: Mr. Beckington

utterance: Who is he going to marry ?
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: Margaret Fremiet.
speaker: Mr. Beckington

utterance: Gracious goodness! what an ex- alted marriage! She's awfully nice, though. But, Clarence, why should Philip look so unhappy when he's going to be married ? Did you look like that when you were engaged?
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: I tried to keep up a pretty cheer- ful exterior when I was with you, but I can assure you that at other times I looked much more un- happy than Philip.
speaker: Mr. Beckington

utterance: It's getting dark, you'd better stop posing, You haven't been talking this afternoon, Jenny; have you got a headache?
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: I didn't know whether you'd like to see me so soon again, but I have got so used to com- ing here in the afternoon that now the portrait is done I want to come just the same.
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance: Indeed, I am glad you came. Take oil your things, Dorothy, and we will have some tea. I have j ust finished working.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: May I make the tea? You're tired ; let me,
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance: Oh, I'm not a bit tired; I've been sitting up on that ladder until I am glad to move around. Do you think you would spoil your regal garments if you came with me into the kitchen ? It's Chloe's afternoon out, and I have promised to make a pudding for din- ner. It will only take a few minutes, and then we will toast some muffins.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: What a dear place, It looks like a doll's kitchen. How cunning the shining kettles are, hung up by their tails. Our kitchen is perfectly horrid down in the basement, and the cook is so cross that I wouldn't go down there for anything.
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance: Do you think it is a pretty room?
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: Dorothy, you mustn't envy me, Although I am awfully happy, it's taken years and years of hard work learning to do the things that you think so original. Do you know I would give it all, the best pic- ture that I have ever painted, or shall paint, to be able to look back to the happy childhood that you are having ? I never had any girlhood ; it was all hard work and dingy studios. Do you remember talking the other day of the pretty things you were going to wear to the Patriarchs' ? I really envied you. I am twenty-five and I've never been to a ball.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: Why, you dear little thing, Haven't you really ever been to a ball? Then in a tone of real sympathy: Didn't you have a com- ing-out tea?
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance: Coming-out tea! When I was your age I had one gown and two paint aprons. Chloe and I lived in a tiny apartment under an attic roof in Paris. Coming- out tea! I'd have been thankful for any kind of a tea. Al- though I'm so thin I've an enormous appetite, and most of the time I was positively hungry. Don't mind my getting excited over the recollection of it,
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: Mind? There were positively tears in Dorothy's blue eyes. You are so little and frail-looking that when you break out in that bitter way it makes me feel dreadfully. You ought to have had some one look after you; it's terrible for a girl to work so hard. Alida, were you ever engaged ?
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance: No, my dear.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: Not even the least little bit?
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance: No, I'm afraid not even the least little bit. One of the men in the studio used to wash my paint brushes every afternoon. He was a big Eng- lishman and painted very badly in the English way; he didn't even wash paint brushes well. I couldn't pos- sibly have been in love with any one who did such awful work. I'm afraid I have been too busy to have had many romances.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: I've been engaged for two years,
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance: You ! You're only eighteen,
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: Doesn't even your mother know ?
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: No; do you suppose I was going to be engaged before I came out? Every one would have called us the babes in the wood, as they did Alice Larkin last year. No, indeed; it's such fun being secretly engaged, so exciting meeting for a moment on the stairs, or in the conservatory at a dance, and to have to pretend we aren't glad when we have been sent into din- ner together. Oh, he's been so ter- ribly jealous.
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance: You funny girl, one moment you are all for romance and the next you are so practical. I don't understand you one bit,
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: I've worn my engagement ring around my neck for two years, and it would seem stupid to wear it on my finger now,
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance: Sapphire means con- stancy, You may read the inscription.
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance: Dorothy from J. A.,' November 1, 1890.' Dor- othy, do you know anything about J. A.? I am older than you, dear, and although I don't know much about the world, I'm sure with your fortune you ought to be very careful.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: Yes, dear, that's just it, Mamma has always told me how aw- ful men are and that they would want to marry me for my money. Don't you think I can be pretty sure of a man who loved me when I was a schoolgirl with those awful half -long dresses and two thin pigtails?
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance: Yes, dear, I think you could; and if J. A. is Mr. Ashley, who has been, I have been told, your devoted slave this winter, it is all right, but I'd tell my mother if I were you.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: I'll think about it,
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance: Dorothy, I never had many girl friends. It's so sweet in you to come and see me so often, and for you to tell me about your engagement, that it doesn't seem quite fair for me to say that I have never been engaged. Dorothy, dear, you mustn't be sur- prised if some day quite soon I tell you that I am engaged too.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: Yes?
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: I am going away, dear.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: Isn't it very sudden? you didn't think of going yesterday.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: When I said I was going away, I did not mean I was going on a jour- ney. Alida his face contracted with pain I am going to tell you something, dear he stopped I love you, I have said it and nothing will make me unsay it.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: I told you that I loved you yes- terday, do you expect me to tell you so every day?
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: Alida, dear, I shall never ask you to tell me so again. Never again shall I kiss you or hold your hands or even come here. I ought not to have spoken as I did yesterday.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: Tell me, dear,
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: When I was a mere college lad I fell in love with a very lovely woman, a married woman. You know I am much older than you are, Alida, and of course a man of my age has many things in his past life. This lady is one of the best and noblest women I have ever known. Her husband has just died do you realize that I can marry no one else, that I am bound to her by every tie of honor?
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: Yes.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: Forgive me, Alida; forget that mad hour yesterday.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: No, she said, clinching her little hands together in passion. Forgive you what for? For giving me the happiest hours of my life? Forget what you said yesterday no ! that is my half hour, all that I shall have to live on all my life. You may marry whom you will, but that half hour you loved me, you were mine.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: You mustn't mind so, Philip; it's not so hard for me as you think. I've never been very happy. I've been alone all my life. I am afraid I am not like other girls who have homes and people to love them no one has ever loved me but Chloe and you.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: Alida, you will break my heart don't you realize don't tempt me, dear.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: Tempt you ? no. The man I love will do what is right. You must go now.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: Good-by.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: Good-by.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: I cannot let you go,
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: Good-by, my dear little love,
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance:
MY DEAR MADAME FKEMIET:

 You will pardon the liberty of my addressing you in this abrupt manner, but I think you ought to know that your devoted admirer, Mr. Her- ford, has during your absence in Europe been paying a great deal of attention to another young lady. As she is an orphan, living by herself, with but few friends, I have taken this opportunity to clear up her posi- tion regarding Mr. Herford, as it may be a source of great unhappiness to her in the future. Please believe that not malicious intentions but a sincere love for the young lady in question, who is Miss Alida Craig, an artist whose studio is in the Sherburne Building, prompts me to write you. I am also a sincere admirer of your great talents and noble character.
Believe me,
Very sincerely,
UNKNOWN.
speaker: UNKNOWN

utterance:
May I ask, if I
have the pleasure of speaking to
Madame Fremiet whom I have seen
play so often?
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance:
Yes, I am Margaret Fremiet. Your por-
trait of Dorothy Mason is so charm-
ing I wondered if you'd do one of
me.
speaker: Margaret Fremiet

utterance:
Do you really mean that you will
sit to me for a portrait ?  It would be such an opportunity. I
have seen you in every character you
play. The first time I went to the
theatre I saw you play Juliet but
perhaps it bores you to have me talk
about your acting?
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance:
No, indeed. One admirer, whose opinion I value,
means more to me than columns of
newspaper notices. So you saw me
play Juliet. I shall never play Juliet
again. I suppose it is a first warning
that an actress gets that she is no
longer young when she realizes that
her Juliet is no longer as artistic as
it was. You are fond of the thea-
tre?
speaker: Margaret Fremiet

utterance:
Oh, very. I have never known
any one before who played.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance:
I shall not act much longer.  To tell the truth, I am
not well all's not right here about
my heart, as Hamlet says. The rest
of my life, if there is going to be a
rest of it, will have to be a quiet one.
After my season closes here I shall
only play once in a while for charity,
as Nilsson does. But what about the
portrait?
speaker: Margaret Fremiet

utterance:
Could I do you in character as
Imogen or Portia? No, I think I
would rather do you just as you sit in
that chair. Might I try some back-
grounds?
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: You look tired. can't I give you a cup of tea?
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: I must be going.
speaker: Margaret Fremiet

utterance:
I am very superstitious about the
breaking of bread. I
was so dull and lonely when you came
in, and we have had such a charming
afternoon, that I should like to have
you drink a cup of tea with me for
companionship.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance:
You are romantic, a bad quality in an un-
sentimental age. But you have such
a charmingly miscellaneous collection
of utensils to make your tea with that
I can't refuse you. I don't doubt
artistic tea is very much better than
the ordinary kind.
speaker: Margaret Fremiet

utterance:
I suppose that I've got to get used to
living along every day and getting as
much happiness and good out of each
person and thing as I can, and be
thankful. When I'm an old lady,
and of course I shall live to be a very,
very old lady, I shall show that cup
to people and tell them that the cele-
brated Madame Fremiet drank tea out
of it. I don't see quite why I take
this so hard. What a baby I am. All
the life seems to have been taken out
of me. I've had harder times than
this, too; it isn't nearly as hard really
as the time when Chloe was so sick in
Paris and all the money was gone. I
thought she would die and leave me
alone then there was that awful
night when she was so delirious, when
I'd had nothing to eat all day and a ter-
rible storm came up and almost blew
in the windows. "What a wild night it
was. How the wind blows.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance:
I was just going by, and I thought to
myself, there's Miss Craig up there
going to eat her little dinner all by
herself, and I'll just carry her home
with me. Come, dear, jump into an-
other dress or bring it around to my
house and dress there. Dorothy
Mason and Mr. Ashley are coming to
dinner and we will have a gay party.
speaker: Mrs. Beckington
Alida Craig

utterance:
You dear boy, I've left
them at dinner just to see you alone
for a moment and congratulate you.
Clarence has told me. I am so glad !
speaker: Mrs. Beckington
Philip Herford

utterance:
Only Dorothy Mason and Mr.
Ashley, and catching sight of the
glove there's Miss Craig's glove.
Philip, I -was up in Miss Craig's studio
this afternoon and I brought her
down to dinner. She was sitting by
the fire and looked so miserable and
blue that my heart just ached for her.
I'm afraid she is in some trouble; she
has always been so bright and gay
before. I wish I knew her well enough
to ask her confidence, but I don't
do you?
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance:
No. We all
treat you like a baby, Bertha, you are
so soft-hearted, he said; we only
have to give you a hint, and without
asking why or wherefore you do just
the right thing.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance:
Clarence said he wanted me to be
nice to her. It's very sweet of you to
say I do the right thing. I often
think that I blunder around like a
beetle; you see I just do things with-
out very much reason. Clarence laughs
at me so; he says that I haven't a bit
of analytical mind.
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance:
No, dear, you haven't, and I am
glad of it. Deliver me from a woman
with an analytical mind. Now, if I
am going to stay this evening, I want
you to tell Miss Craig very quietly
before she comes upstairs that I am
here.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance:
I do not want you to tell me any-
thing. You don't need to.
You are all the brother I've got, and
I can't help saying that I am sorry,
oh, so sorry, for you and her.
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: I am so sorry too.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance:
It's so nice of you to think I am
original. you are very
good about it, but some people seem
to think me a new kind of animal
whose habits and customs are to be
studied like Mr. Crowley's; they never
seem to realize that I have lived so
long in studios and among artists
that anything different seems original
to me. The idea of living in a whole
house strikes me as positively odd.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance:
You wouldn't find it odd, my
dear. You'd find it a perfect bore if you
had to look after a house. I'd like to
live as you do, housekeeping is such a
care.
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance:
Yes, poor Bertha, said her hus-
band, patting her plump shoulder,
 she's a wreck from her household
cares. But where do you suppose
Gordon White is? He was to have
dined with us, and he didn't come or
send any word. We are really very
much worried about him, for you know
how punctilious he is.
speaker: Clarence Beckington

utterance:
I'm afraid he went to buy that
doll for you, Bertha, said her brother,
seeing that they were really anxious
about their old friend. He's prob-
ably got lost, and Clarence will have
to advertise for him. ' A middle-aged
bachelor, answering to the name of
either Gordon or White, went to buy
a doll for Mrs. Beckington; hasn't
been heard of since. ' That will sound
finely in the Evening Moon, won't
it?
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance:
I wouldn't be such a tease if I
were you; probably he is sick or
something, and you'll be sorry for
having made fun of him. I think
Mr. White is just the nicest man in
the world and I won't have fun poked
at him.
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: Where have you been ?
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance:
It's the doll I got for you, he
said, smiling, and there are a few
more things in the cab.
speaker: Gordon White

utterance:
I got it at Macy's, he said, ex-
citedly.  Did you ever go to Macy's ?
I asked the waiter at the club where
to buy a doll, and he said Macy's, so I
went there. It was just like the Stock
Exchange, only women. There were
so many dolls it was hard work decid-
ing, but I thought this was a very nice
one. Its eyes open and shut, and the
young person assured me that its
clothes come off. It's got a good cry,
too.
speaker: Gordon White

utterance:
I bought a tin kitchen, he went
on. The young person said,
'Wouldn't you like a tin kitchen?
They are greatly reduced; only sixty-
seven cents ; such a bargain ! ' I never
got anything at a bargain in my life,
so I thought I'd get the tin kitchen.
I suppose now so many girls go to
college there isn't such a demand
for kitchens as there used to be.
speaker: Gordon White

utterance:
Just think of inculcating domes-
ticity in some little girl, said Philip,
picking up the toy, by giving her a
tin kitchen at a cost of sixty-seven
cents. I know what I shall give you
for Christmas, Dorothy, only I sup-
pose you'd like to have one made of
silver.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance:
No, I wouldn't. Do let me take
it.
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance: May I play with it too ?
speaker: Jim Ashley

utterance:
I did not know you were here
when I came.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance:
It's just as well. I am glad that you
stayed.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance:
Do you suppose that is Shem or
Ham? cried Mrs. Beckington, hold-
ing up a small, straight, red figure.
 I want to be sure, so as to have him
in the right place in the proces-
sion.
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance:
What an excellent Sunday-school
scholar you must have been to remem-
ber their names, dear. Do you re-
member their wives' names too ?
speaker: Clarence Beckington

utterance:
Make a friend of Bertha. My hands are tied;
though you are in need, though you
are dying, I may not stir to help you.
Bertha is the sweetest soul alive, and
if you are friends it will make me feel
easier.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance:
Do you think that is a dicky bird
or a chicken? said Mr. Beckington,
unwrapping a nondescript yellow
biped.
speaker: Clarence Beckington

utterance:
I don't know, answered his wife
reflectively. It looks to me like a
lizard, only it's got but two legs.
Here's a pine tree, she cried trium-
phantly. I wonder why they had
pine trees in the ark?
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: For Christmas trees, of course.
speaker: Gordon White

utterance:
I would like you to think kindly
of one of us.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance:
Think kindly of you! I always shall. She raised
her clear dark eyes and looked straight
into his face with fearless strength.
I have missed you so much, she
said.  I can't help it, but 1 suppose
I shall get used to it. Some time
when I'm a little old lady still paint-
ing away in my studio, and you're an
old, old man, you will come and see
me again, won't you ?
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance:
Jim isn't a bit nice, called out
Dorothy from her corner. He
won't let me have his cigarette papers
to burn in the range. Oh, do make
him give them to me, Mrs. Becking-
ton!
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance:
Do you remember the day I was
doing that tapestry design, went on
Alida, when you read me Arnold's
' Tristran and Iseult ' ? I often think
of it now how they sat together after
their restless, burning lives,
' ' ' Telling tales of separated lovers
Reunited at their end at last. '
It may be many years, but you
can think of me always at work and
always loving you.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: God bless you.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: What are you doing, Mr. White?
speaker: Dorothy Mason

What have you been playing to-
night ?  Ah, but I know
Portia. You have always something
judicial in your mien afterward. I
went to your hotel this afternoon, but
you were away. May I come to-mor-
row?

utterance: Supper is served.
speaker: UNKNOWN

utterance: Lots of young ladies
speaker: Mr. Blair

utterance: Mr. Blair, I don't think Miss Craig or her friends can ever thank you enough for coming and letting us know of this. I think, perhaps, I can prevent the article being published; my father owns some stock in the Evening Budget^ and one of my cousins is on the staff Tom Ashley, perhaps you know him ?
speaker: Jim Ashley

utterance: Oh, yes; he's the sporting editor. I guess he could fix it for you.
speaker: Mr. Blair

utterance: Thank you very much, Mr. Blair
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: You won't let on 'twas me ?
speaker: Mr. Blair

utterance: No, indeed, and thank you for coming.
speaker: Jim Ashley

utterance: Wasn't it good of Mm? I just hope he will get to be a reporter and an editor and everything else that is fine.
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance: Do you really think you can stop the article ?
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: I'll do the best I can, only you must excuse my asking the question, but are you engaged to Mr. Herford or not?
speaker: Jim Ashley

utterance: Then I'm off; I'll tell them they can print anything they like about your pictures or studio, but nothing personal. Now don't worry one bit. Tommy Ashley will fix the whole thing up for me in a jiffy; he's the best sort. Dorothy will stay with you until I come back.
speaker: Jim Ashley

utterance: Oh, go, do, you dear, good, big boy
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: Yes, go
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance: I am better, but so lazy and tired. Don't worry about me. I shall be up to-morrow, and will be able to finish out my engagement.
speaker: Margaret Fremiet

utterance: Good night.
speaker: Margaret Fremiet

utterance: Don't go; Paderewski is going to play. Kim up in the library, it will be perfectly quiet there. Stay, Philip, do ; you look so white and ashy that I can't bear to have you go. I'll turn all the women out first.
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: I've just had some new Elzevirs sent over from the Due de Komarteau's sale at the Hotel Drouot. Won't you come up to the library and see them?
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: You see, Dorothy, you wouldn't have it announced, and I  I'm
speaker: Jim Ashley

utterance: Mr. Ashley, member of the Calu-
speaker: Jim Ashley

utterance: You ought to be ashamed of yourself, Jim Ashley, flirting so when you know I love you with all my heart and soul! Oh
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance: May I ask, Jim, what is the meaning of your corral- ing my sister's guests and scaring them into hysterics ?
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: If I were you, I shouldn't be the least bit discouraged. I'd go right downstairs now and find Dorothy; she's probably nearer giv- ing in than she's ever been before. I'd run right along.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: Wait a moment.
speaker: Jim Ashley

utterance: We are going to walk around
speaker: Jim Ashley

utterance: I'll come and see you to-morrow morning
speaker: Jim Ashley

utterance: Oh, Clarence, I'm so hungry.
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: Are you, dear ? I'll go down and see if there isn't some supper left.
speaker: Clarence Beckington

utterance: No, I don't want salads and things ; I wish oh how I wish I had a pie!
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: Go down and forage, that's a dear, get some- thing good, we can eat it up here. I don't doubt the servants have pies and all sorts of good things that we never have.
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: Jenny, time's up.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: You'll come and pose for me now and then after you are married, won't you, Jenny? just to keep my eye for color up to the mark.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: I'm going to be married like a lady
speaker: Jenny Brady

utterance: I can't decide a bit, To tell the truth, Miss Craig, there's one I'd like to have better than any of these, but I don't know as you'll like to give it to me. It's that woman on the wall. You see I've always had to keep my eyes on her when I've been posing; I thought she was aw- fully ugly at first, but somehow she kind of growed on me. It had a look of you, some way, and it would kind of remind me of you and the posing.
speaker: Jenny Brady

utterance: You can certainly have that; it's a photograph, and I'll get you one like it, You can have a water color too
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: "I can't be alone like this,"
speaker: herself

utterance: "It just kills me. There's Miss "Wells going out to din- ner, and it's such a rainy night. I wonder if she won't stay with me. Miss Wells ah, Miss Wells ! "
speaker: herself

utterance: " won't you come and dine with me ? You'll cer- tainly melt away if you go out in this pour. Chloe is concocting the most delicious gumbo; please come and share it."
speaker: herself

utterance: "ISTo reasonable offer refused,"
speaker: Rosamond Wells

utterance: " But just wait for a moment until I put away my umbrella and gums. You'll excuse evening dress, I presume, but if not I'll put on a white tie."
speaker: Rosamond Wells

utterance: " You needn't mind about the tie."
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: "How jolly this is! I'd like to keep house myself if only I could find a twin sis- ter of the invaluable Chloe. But the nine maids in one month, which was my last effort in the domestic line, have made me very well content with cheerless restaurant dinners. After all, a woman can't do everything. Sometimes I think it would be real nice to have a quiet, domestic little husband who would look after things while I was downtown. I'd make him feel real self-respecting why, I'd give him an allowance. Gumbo! Young woman, if you don't appreciate the blessing of a woman who can really make it, you deserve, late in life, to be catered for by a raw Swede my ninth was a Swede."
speaker: Rosamond Wells

utterance: "Won't you carve? I carve so badly."
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: " A dinner of two and a duck is perfect, because every one gets the best piece. You artists are so delightful, your things never match. Now I always used to have my things in sets until I came to live here; now I'm perfectly content with the debris the nine left me. Won't you ask your- self to have another piece of duck, as you are hostess? "
speaker: Rosamond Wells

utterance: " No more, thank you,"
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: " You look pale do you know it, my child ? There are great rings under your eyes; you've been working too hard, I suppose. Is that the picture you're doing ? Is it done ? I always like an artist to tell me when things are done; one's never sure, especially lately; you wouldn't really think that things were commenced. I'm not really a judge, but I should suppose that it was very fine if one knew. I'm sure I hope that some one will buy it, and that you will get a real good price."
speaker: Rosamond Wells

utterance: "It's not done yet, nothing like; there are lots of things to be done to it. Now, although you carve so well, I know you can't dress a salad. Wait until you see how this one turns out ; I think you will like it ; There, is that just right ? "
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: "Perfection. A little more salt, please; there's nothing suits me quite like a Eussian salad."
speaker: Rosamond Wells

utterance: "Have you been downstairs lately to see Mrs. Bohm? Katie, who chores for me, said this morning that her little boy was terribly sick. You know her, don't you?"
speaker: Rosamond Wells

utterance: "Know Mary Bohm of course I do; we were students together in Paris. Oh, why haven't I been down to see her?"
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: " Do you think it is too late to go now?"
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: "Well, Katie said the child was terribly sick; it's awful her being there alone with him. I wanted to go myself, only I was afraid of intrud- ing. You can see if there is a light in the room, and if there is, knock softly. If there is anything I can do, call on me. I sleep like a log, but I'm not afraid and I'll leave the door un- locked. Good-night, dear little girl. ' '
speaker: Rosamond Wells

utterance: " Dear me, how slight and frail she is; she's fallen away in the last week; she ought to have some- one to look after her. How I wish I was her mother. Wouldn't it be fine to have a great girl like that to come home to?"
speaker: Rosamond Wells

utterance: "Mary Mary Bohm, it is I, Alida Craig."
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: " I'm all in disorder, But Tommy's been so ill that I've been up night and day; I'm half sick for sleep."
speaker: Mary Bohm

utterance: " I'll stay and sit by Tommy while you get some rest,"
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: "Yes, I've had a hard time this winter. I've sold all my pretty things. I don't mind your knowing it now. I sup- pose I haven't any pride left, though I've kept quiet and not answered your knock lots of times this winter, for fear you'd know."
speaker: Mary Bohm

utterance: "Make him another poultice, Alida, It's pneu- monia, and there's nothing to do but keep up the poultices. I'm so worn out that I forgot it, and the last one must be cold."
speaker: Mary Bohm

utterance: " Mary, keep your eyes open just a moment, I must go up- stairs for something."
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: "Have some port, Mary, and eat some of those sandwiches ; there's no use trying to take care of Tommy by making yourself ill too."
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: "I was faint, I guess. Alida Craig, you've come like an angel."
speaker: Mary Bohm

utterance: " Go out in the studio and lie down ; we can put this cot out there, and then if Tommy wakes he won't disturb you. Come, I'U fix it."
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: "Where do your family live?"
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: "Washburn, Indiana, and they don't know a painting from a chromo. I'd rather die than go back there. You're the strangest girl, Alida; you've always been so lucky; the way you used to have number one in the concours month after month, and the luck you've had since you came home; yet I've always felt that you never cared half so much about your work as I did. Why, I've half starved to stay here these last two months and paint a picture for the Society. It's almost done there on the easel."
speaker: Mary Bohm

utterance: "Is Tommy all right?"
speaker: Mary Bohm

utterance: "Yes, dear."
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: " I'll go to sleep in a moment; I'm beginning to be quite drowsy. I want you to do something forme."
speaker: Mary Bohm

utterance: "Yes."
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: " Light a candle there's one on the mantelpiece and look at the picture. I'd sleep easier if I really had some one's opinion."
speaker: Mary Bohm

utterance: "I think it's the best thing you have done, but I don't want to say any more until I have seen it by day- light,"
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: "My watch is "
speaker: Rosamond Wells

utterance: " Oh, it's you, Alida Craig. Is the child worse what can I do ? "
speaker: Rosamond Wells

utterance: "His mother's afraid he's dying; he's suddenly taken worse. Would you go out with Chloe for the doctor ? Chloe, you know, can't find her way around New York one bit."
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: "Where is it?"
speaker: Rosamond Wells

utterance: "Fifty-eighth Street."
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: " Don't you mind about Chloe, I'm not one bit afraid to go by myself; only wake her up and have her go down to Mrs. Bohm's. There's some whiskey in that closet ; you'd better give me a drop and take some your- self; you're a ghost."
speaker: Rosamond Wells

utterance: " You ought not to go alone, Suppose some one should stop you ? "
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: " Nonsense, child ; at the rate I'll go they'll think I am an escaped lunatic. If they did stop me, I'd just say, ' I'm going for the doctor ; wait here until I come back and I'll blow your head off.' Good-by, I'll be back in ten minutes. "
speaker: Rosamond Wells

utterance: "I'll make some coffee,"
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: " I'll make it ; and, Mrs. Bohm, do light a fire, it's perishingly cold."
speaker: Rosamond Wells

utterance: " The child is doing well now. Unless something unforeseen arises he will get along now. Thank you, Miss "Wells,"
speaker: the doctor

utterance: "You are sure that Tommy will get well? "
speaker: Mary Bohm

utterance: " Yes, quite sure ; only when he is recovered I should advise a country life. He's rather a delicate child. I wouldn't try to bring him up in the city. Now, ladies, good-morning; go to bed and sleep as long as you can, as I am going to do. I'll be around in the afternoon ; your maid will stay with the child until I can send a nurse, I believe. Good-morning. "
speaker: the doctor

utterance: " Up since three in the morning and I've never turned a hair,"
speaker: Rosamond Wells

utterance: "Don't feel, that I am throwing Mr. Herford over for you, or that I shall marry you be- cause I do not marry Mr. Herford. I just know that this thing will be ; that it is my fate, and that we must all accept it. But time must work out the problem as it will; I cannot hurry it; I don't know anything."
speaker: Margaret Fremiet

utterance: " It's all very wonderful, I don't understand it, and I do. It's an awkward position for me, but since you say Herford would gladly be re- leased, I do not see that I am harm- ing him in any attitude that I take. I am good at waiting, and I might just as well go up to the Adirondacks to shoot for a little while as go home to England. Besides, it will be easier to get back from there; all you will have to do is to wire, ' Come. ' "
speaker: the Duke of Axminster

utterance: " Oh, Duke, why can- not I love you in return ? Why am I giving myself to you so coldly? I despise myself ; it is sacrificing you. I ought not to marry you."
speaker: Margaret Fremiet

utterance: " You don't know at all, I accepted it so long ago that it's more than I ever hoped or dreamed for that you would be my wife at all. I'nr happy, happy do you under- stand? I don't care whether you love me or not; I don't want to think of it or talk of it; I love you, that's enough, that's all."
speaker: the Duke of Axminster

utterance: " Good-by, my duchess,"
speaker: the Duke of Axminster

utterance: "I suppose it's finished now,"
speaker: Rosamond Wells

utterance: "It's never going to be finished ; I haven't worked on it for a long time. Perhaps you don't know how bad it is, but it's awful. I saw it just as plain as day the night Tommy was so sick. All my things have been bad straight from the start. I used to hate Alida when she was in Julian's, the way she got ahead. I wanted to succeed so, to get ahead of every one, to be ad- mired. That isn't Art, and I don't wonder I didn't do any better. I've never had the least notion of the real thing, like that little creature upstairs, who lives in her work."
speaker: Mary Bohm

utterance: " She's a good girl and gentle and modest,"
speaker: Rosamond Wells

utterance: "I've thought my painting very fine, but I don't believe it's any too good for Indiana. They're proud of me out there, and I guess, after all, home's the best place for most women."
speaker: Mary Bohm

utterance: "It will seem lonely without them, Though I declare, for all the tramping up and down stairs and bearing with that poor girl's temper, you look stronger than you did. You needn't worry about her; she's taken off her black, I notice, and when a girl starts off on a journey with as well-fitting a gown as that, it shows that she is beginning to pick up. Now, you'd better come and lunch with me. If I've money enough left after buying that leaping kangaroo we'll go to Del's. And I've two seats for the Lohengrin matinee. I'd like you to come with me ever so much that is, if you're not so musical that you want a score. I hate a score."
speaker: Rosamond Wells

utterance: " No, I don't know one note from another, but I should love to hear Lohengrin again."
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: " Come along, then ; there's nothing like the opera for me. I go and blub- ber, and I love it all straight up from the swan. As for the dragon in Siegfried, I'm devotedly attached to it. Let's walk down, the sunshine is so inviting, and I have my best neck- tie on, which always makes me feel a cut above the Fourth Avenue car."
speaker: Rosamond Wells

utterance: " Lor' sakes, it's Mam'zell Margaret."
speaker: Chloe

utterance: " Chloe, Chloe, my dear, dear Chloe! "
speaker: Margaret Fremiet

utterance: "How beautiful you is! You isn't a day older than you was, 'pears to me. There weren't never no one as pretty as you. Old Chloe never thought her old eyes would see you again."
speaker: Chloe

utterance: "Won't you come back again and be my maid ? you know you really belong to me."
speaker: Margaret Fremiet

utterance: "I can't leave Miss 'Lida, I b'longed to you sure 'nuff, Mam'zell, but I can't leave Miss' Lida; she belongs to me, I've had her ever since she was born."
speaker: Chloe

utterance: "Ever since she was born ! "
speaker: Margaret Fremiet

utterance: "When had Chloe left New Orleans ? What had she done all the time? When had she met Miss Craig ?"
speaker: Margaret Fremiet

utterance: " Chloe, do you remember my last night at home? "
speaker: Margaret Fremiet

utterance: " Yes,"
speaker: Chloe

utterance: "Chloe, you know how miserable my marriage was ; I was so excited and happy with my success in the play that night, that I fairly forgot how terrible Monsieur Bonaventure could be, and I went to him, radiant with success, thinking he would sympathize with me and let me go on the stage. He was terrible, and we had a most fearful quarrel; we had had so many quarrels and had said so many bitter things that I suppose he thought he could say any- thing he liked, but he went a little too far that night, and I was so angry that I walked straight out of the house."
speaker: Margaret Fremiet

utterance: "There, there, did you ever think your baby would be a woman grown now if she had lived ? "
speaker: Chloe

utterance: " If she had lived ! Chloe, did she live ? Do you know anything "
speaker: Margaret Fremiet

utterance: Did you never hear from Massa all this time?
speaker: Chloe

utterance: Certainly he was a hard man.
speaker: Chloe

utterance: Hard and unforgiving. But he is dead; he sent me a message from his death- bed, thanking me for never having played in New Or- leans.
speaker: Margaret

utterance: So he's dead.
speaker: Chloe

utterance: So he's dead. He was a hard man ; he turned me out of doors with the baby, Mam'zell, the day after you went away ; he was like the devil himself. I thought he'd kill me and the child, and they said he burnt up every scrap of your dresses and things that you left. He gave me a little bit of money every year to take care of the child, but he swore me never to tell her who she was ; he even made me give her an- other name.
speaker: Chloe

utterance: My baby's name was Margaret, like mine.
speaker: Margaret

utterance: I called her Alida.
speaker: Chloe

utterance: Alida ! Alida !
speaker: Margaret

utterance: Tell me all about her, ' '
speaker: Margaret

utterance: Chloe, you have kept your promise to Monsieur Bonaventure very faithfully. I want you to keep a promise to me. You must never, never let Alida know that I am her mother.
speaker: Margaret

utterance: And you so sick, too, Mam'zell,
speaker: Chloe

utterance: She'd be such a comfort to you.
speaker: Chloe

utterance: The fathers, what do they say ?
speaker: Margaret

utterance: That the child is dead. Monsieur Bonaventure told them so on his death-bed; her existence would in- validate their bequest.
speaker: Tommy Barlow

utterance: Mr. Barlow, there is no record of the child's death that I know and yet she is dead. If the fathers are content with their posses- sion, very well ; strengthen them in the belief that the child died shortly after I left New Orleans. I am will- ing, if necessary, to add to the legacy if it will aid in keeping the very sad events of my early life undisturbed in their oblivion.
speaker: Margaret

utterance: You seem in a melting mood to- day, Margaret. You've only three more nights to play, and yet we seem as far from our wedding day as ever. I would not have thought you would be so coquettish ; tell me when you will be mine?
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: Never !
speaker: Margaret

utterance: Margaret, what do you mean?
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: I mean what I say, Philip. We have been such ideal lovers, why marry and have all the romance taken away ? I really don't mean to marry you ; I'm in earnest. In fact I don't think you have cared for me much lately. You know things travel so easily ; I've heard all about Miss Craig and your devotion to her. Ah, Philip, you always had such good taste in the fine arts ; hav- ing wearied of the footlights, have you found fresh charms in the palette and brushes?
speaker: Margaret

utterance: Margaret, this is unworthy of you. It's not like you to be jealous; you are my affianced wife; you have had all my love and devotion for years; why should you be jealous?
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: One often doesn't possess qual- ities until occasion develops them. Flippantly: I have never had any cause to be jealous until now.
speaker: Margaret

utterance: Trust me now, dear.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: Philip, do you really love me? Tell me so once more, won't you?
speaker: Margaret

utterance: I love you, Margaret.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: Well, I don't love you ; I'm tired of you. I didn't know how tired until it came to my taking the irrevocable step of marrying you.
speaker: Margaret

utterance: It is better to hurt your vanity and mine than to go on and find that we have made a terrible mistake ; you know that we all have two sides to our natures. I don't think that you have ever quite realized the other side of mine. You have appealed to what is best in me, fostered it, brought it out ; but the other side is there, and lately it has come upper- most. I love power and fame and glory ; and just as years ago I walked out of my home without a pang, and left it to go on the stage, so, now that my stage life must come to an end, I cannot settle down to the dull round that you call society in JS"ew York ; I must have more power and position than you can give me. I can leave you as easily as I took that other step, to have what I most desire in my new life. Love you !
speaker: Margaret

utterance: I love myself. I think it is better to have a real coronet of strawberry leaves than a crown of withered senti- ments. Will you be the first to con- gratulate the future Duchess of Ax- minster?
speaker: Margaret

utterance: Margaret, my dear, I do not think you quite mean that being my wife wouldn't somewhat palliate the dulness of New York society. I don't know exactly what you mean, except that you have taken some jealous freak about Miss Craig. As you say, my dear, we all have two sides to our natures, and I can scarcely think that one so generous-hearted as yourself would think it the worst side of mine that I befriended a little, helpless, hard-working girl, whose chief attrac- tion, when I first met her, was that she reminded me vaguely of you.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: We may talk all day, Philip, but it cannot change the fact that I am tired of you, and that, to tell the truth, you are tired of me. As long as I thought you adored me, I fancied myself indis- pensable ; you see even in me there remains a vestige of the eternally feminine unnecessary sacrifice. When I heard of your devotion to Miss Craig I saw clearly that I had worn out my charmingly aesthetic but hard- ly human passion for you. Do you think that my heart, which has beat to the admiration of thousands, would be content with the perfunctory atten- tions of a husband who had wearied of me as a lover?
speaker: Margaret

utterance: Go and marry your little artist and live in Arcadia, and I will go and be a duchess
speaker: Margaret

utterance: Margaret, you have never been heartless ; if you have decided that you do not love me, and that you do love Axminster, say so ; let us part, if we must, in kindness and respect.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: I do love Axminster, Philip ; I was glad when I heard that you had grown attached to Miss Craig. We have lived in a dream of a vague poetic fancy, but that is not the way I love Axminster.
speaker: Margaret

utterance: I hope you will be happy, dear,
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: Good-by.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: Come, Dorothy, and see the pic- ture ; it's signed and finished.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: What is the matter? Why did you come?
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: I I came for some tea. What a glorious picture ; are you going to send it to the Society?
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: I've come to tell you that I am free to marry you, Alida.
speaker: Philip Herford

utterance: Why, you haven't had that tea you came for, yet, I must make it. Dorothy will be com- ing along in a minute, and she always clamors for something to eat.
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: It's all over ; we're engaged.
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance: I'm so glad, dear,
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: Was your mother much upset?
speaker: Alida Craig

utterance: Upset ! no, in the utmost exas- peration. No; it's perfectly dis- heartening. It seems she wanted us to marry all along. Did you ever know anything so commonplace ? I hoped at least she'd refuse her consent.
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance: Everything is so dull and com- monplace now, isn't it, Jim?
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance: Is everything so dull and common- place now?
speaker: Jim Ashley

utterance: Yes ; it isn't like the old times, when you used to have to snatch a kiss when no one was by.
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance: No one is by now,
speaker: Jim Ashley

utterance: I hoped mother would refuse her consent, but you're so disgustingly eligible. Just think if you had been penniless or not in society, or any- thing terrible, and we should have had to elope !
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance: But really, Dorothy, I don't think your mother would have liked you to elope.
speaker: Jim Ashley

utterance: What a silly thing to say! You haven't a spark of romance in you.
speaker: Dorothy Mason

utterance: Very well, then ; I don't think my mother would have liked me to elope. Now, Dorothy, don't let's quarrel. I'll be married in a balloon, or up a tree, or anywhere that strikes you as romantic ; I'm awfully senti- mental about you.
speaker: Jim Ashley

utterance: Don't speak to me; and you needn't shut the door Clarence is coming. Oh, I'm so tired ; I've got the tea shakes. I've drank six cups of tea. Tea ! concoctions of every- thing in the world that is calculated to shatter the nerves. Dorothy, whatever form of enjoyment your mother wishes to take for announcing your engagement, don't let it be a tea. I've been to three announce- ment teas this afternoon such jams ! Eeally, I can't remember whether Mabel Hawkins, in light blue, is going to marry her cousin who is in the army, or whether it is Louise Pome- roy. Madame Calve sang at the Lawrence's, only their house was so crowded you couldn't get near the music room.
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: Why, how did you come here, Philip?
speaker: Mrs. Beckington

utterance: Yes, Mrs. Beckington, I entirely agree with you ; Dorothy and I are firm on one point : we won't have a tea.
